title: Nodes crashing when handling ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINTs

sentences.text: Subjecting a 3 node cluster to a transactional load that includes SAVEPOINTs + ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT statements results in nasty crashes.
Removing the ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT possibility from the test load results in a 'pass'
DBD:mysql (the test uses the randgen / random query generator)
This could be because you hit a bug.
It is also possible that this binary or one of the libraries it was linked against is corrupt, improperly built, or misconfigured.
This error can also be caused by malfunctioning hardware.
We will try our best to scrape up some info that will hopefully help diagnose the problem, but since we have already crashed, something is definitely wrong and this may fail.
It is possible that mysqld could use up to
if not, decrease some variables in the equation.
You can use the following information to find out where mysqld died.
If you see no messages after this, something went terribly wrong...
Some pointers may be invalid and cause the dump to abort.
Here is how one can modify the test to *not* use SAVEPOINTs.
Could this be tied to the possibility that multiple SAVEPOINTs of the same name could be used in the same transaction?
(eg, we don't track try to use them very sensibly, we just pepper them into the mix)
-        SAVEPOINT A /*Generated by THREAD_ID _thread_id*/ |  +	insert_query | update | delete ;
ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT A /*Generated by THREAD_ID _thread_id*/ ;
It should also be noted that simple tests of ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT are passing:
anyways, I got dbqp running, and this test passes, when running from current wsrep-5.5 head:
20111129-102415 INFO Test execution complete in 2175 seconds
20111129-102415 INFO STATUS: PASS, 1/1 test cases, 100.00 percent executed
> anyways, I got dbqp running, and this test passes, when running from > current wsrep-5.5 head:
> 20111129-102415 INFO Test execution complete in 2175 seconds
> 20111129-102415 INFO STATUS: PASS, 1/1 test cases, 100.00 percent executed
Ah, that is because the ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT bit of that randgen test  is disabled (to look for other bugs).
I've created a version that uses ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT.
Try the same  command line, but with suite=cluster_bugs.
This is a new suite I just  added, so you will need to update your dbqp repo.
Finally, apologies for any inconvenience you had using the test  software.
I'm working on updating the docs asap and they will be  available via Drizzle's docs site (and other means).
I pulled the latest dbqp version (r52) and tried with the cluster_bugs suite, full command line is like here:
Result is that the test still passes, here's the output:
20111129-231716 VERBOSE Processing code rooted at basedir: /home/seppo/work/wsrep/wsrep-5.5...
20111129-231722 VERBOSE Executor: bot0 beginning test execution...
20111129-231749 VERBOSE Executor: bot0 executing test: cluster_bugs.bug892274_test
20111130-001225 INFO Test execution complete in 3303 seconds
20111130-001225 INFO STATUS: PASS, 1/1 test cases, 100.00 percent executed
It may also be that current wsrep-5.5 had has a fix for the problem encountered with the original dbqp test run.
There were fixes e.g. for dealing with empty RBR buffers, and savepoint rollbacks can easily generate such...

I'll give this a test myself and see what happens.
I've been using a  somewhat older branch while just getting tests up and running.
Just tested out on my box with updated library + server.
Now on to think of more ways to break things >: )
Apologies, but the test grammar had a flaw.
Rather than mixing SAVEPOINT A and ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT A in a transaction, it was issuing those statements immediately after each other (ie it was  a softball test).
I just tested the fixed test against a fresh pull of the codership-mysql branch and am seeing the crash:
This could be because you hit a bug.
It is also possible that this binary or one of the libraries it was linked against is corrupt, improperly built, or misconfigured.
This error can also be caused by malfunctioning hardware.
We will try our best to scrape up some info that will hopefully help diagnose the problem, but since we have already crashed, something is definitely wrong and this may fail.
It is possible that mysqld could use up to
if not, decrease some variables in the equation.
You can use the following information to find out where mysqld died.
If you see no messages after this, something went terribly wrong...
Some pointers may be invalid and cause the dump to abort.
The manual page at http://dev.mysql.com/doc/mysql/en/crashing.html contains information that should help you find out what is causing the crash.
111129 20:12:03 [ERROR] WSREP: exception from gcomm, backend must be restarted:regexec(PT1S): No match: 22 (Invalid argument)
ok, thanks,  I can reproduce the issue with the latest dbqp version.
I could also extract an offending transaction from the logs.
It turns out also that the problem happens only when binlog has been enabled.
When I commented out the log_bin option in galera.py, the test passes.
